column3: officially the Republic of Angola (Portuguese: _República de Angola_ )

column1: Antarctica;Antarctica ( ) is Earth's southernmost and least-populated continent. Situated almost entirely south of the Antarctic Circle and surrounded by the Southern Ocean (also known as the Antarctic Ocean)

column8: 000 sq mi). Most of Antarctica is covered by the Antarctic ice sheet

column1: Bosnia and Herzegovina;"Bosnia and Herzegovina (Serbo-Croatian: _Bosna i Hercegovina_

column3: officially the Collectivité territoriale de Saint-Barthélemy

column3: is a landlocked country in Eastern Europe. It is bordered by Russia to the east and northeast

Minsk is the capital and largest city; it is administered separately as a city with special status.  Between the medieval period and the 20th century

column11: including Kievan Rus'
column12: the Principality of Polotsk
column13: the Grand Duchy of Lithuania

column3: beh-_; Belize Kriol English: _Bileez_ ) is a country on the north-eastern coast of Central America. It is bordered by Mexico to the north

Belize's institutions and official language reflect its history as a British colony.  The Maya civilization spread into the area of Belize between 1500 BC and AD 300 and flourished until about 1200. Spain and Britain both laid claim to the land until Britain defeated the Spanish in the Battle of St. George's Caye (1798). In 1840 it became a British colony known as British Honduras

column16: and Garifuna. Over half the population is multilingual

column18: its extensive coral reefs
column19: and punta music.  Belize's abundance of terrestrial and marine species and its diversity of ecosystems give it a key place in the globally significant Mesoamerican Biological Corridor. It is considered a Central American and Caribbean nation with strong ties to both the American and Caribbean regions. It is a member of the Caribbean Community (CARICOM)

column1: Bermuda;"Bermuda (; historically known as Las Bermudas or Las Islas Bermudas ) is a British Overseas Territory in the North Atlantic Ocean. The closest land outside the territory is in the American state of North Carolina
column3: 035 km (643 mi) to the west-northwest.  Bermuda is an archipelago consisting of 181 islands

column21: 000 people

column25: while White Bermudians
column26: primarily of British
column27: Irish and Portuguese descent

Bermuda has a distinct dialect of English and has historically had strong ties with other English-speaking countries in the Americas
column29: including the United States

column31: and the Commonwealth Caribbean. It is an associate member of the Caribbean Community.  "

column2: officially the Federative Republic of Brazil (Portuguese: )

column8: 491 kilometers (4

column12: and extensive natural resources spanning numerous protected habitats. This unique environmental heritage positions Brazil at number one of 17 megadiverse countries

The territory which would become known as Brazil was inhabited by numerous tribal nations prior to the landing in 1500 of explorer Pedro Álvares Cabral

column1: Barbados;"Barbados (UK:  _bar- BAY-doss_; US:  _bar- BAY-dohss_; locally  _bər- BAY- dəss_) is an island country in the Lesser Antilles of the West Indies

column12: the colony operated on a plantation economy

column3: officially the Kingdom of Bhutan (Dzongkha: འབྲུག་རྒྱལ་ཁབ་

column12: 824 sq mi) and ranks 133rd in land area and 160th in population. Bhutan is a constitutional monarchy with a king (Druk Gyalpo) as the head of state and a prime minister as the head of government. Vajrayana Buddhism is the state religion and the Je Khenpo is the head of the state religion.  The subalpine Himalayan mountains in the north rise from the country's lush subtropical plains in the south. In the Bhutanese Himalayas
column13: there are peaks higher than 7
column14: 000 metres (23
column15: 000 ft) above sea level. Gangkhar Puensum is Bhutan's highest peak and is the highest unclimbed mountain in the world. The wildlife of Bhutan is notable for its diversity

column27: a treaty guaranteed British advice in foreign policy in exchange for internal autonomy in Bhutan. The arrangement continued under a new treaty with India in 1949 (signed at Darjeeling) in which both countries recognised each other's sovereignty. Bhutan joined the United Nations in 1971. It has since expanded relations with 55 countries. While dependent on the Indian military

column1: Bouvet Island;"Bouvet Island ( _BOO -vay_; Norwegian: _Bouvetøya_ [bʉˈvèːœʏɑ]) is an island and dependency of Norway

column3: officially the Republic of Botswana (Setswana: _Lefatshe la Botswana_
column4: [lɪˈfatsʰɪ la bʊˈtswana])
column5: is a landlocked country in Southern Africa. Botswana is topographically flat
column6: with approximately 70 percent of its territory being the Kalahari Desert. It is bordered by South Africa to the south and southeast
column7: Namibia to the west and north
column8: and Zimbabwe to the northeast. It is connected by the Kazungula Bridge to Zambia

column10: Botswana is one of the most sparsely populated countries in the world. It is essentially the nation state of the Tswana
column11: who make up 79% of the population. About 11.6 per cent of the population lives in the capital and largest city
column12: Gaborone. Formerly one of the world's poorest countries—with a GDP per capita of about US$70 per year in the late 1960s—it has since transformed itself into an upper-middle-income country
column13: with one of the world's fastest-growing economies.  Modern-day humans first inhabited the country over 200
column14: 000 years ago. The Tswana ethnic group were descended mainly from Bantu-speaking tribes who migrated southward of Africa to modern Botswana around 600 CE

column18: it has been a representative republic

Its relatively high gross national income per capita (by some estimates the fourth-largest in Africa) gives the country a relatively high standard of living and the third-highest Human Development Index of continental Sub-Saharan Africa (after Gabon and South Africa). Botswana is the first African country to host Forbes 30 Under 30 and the 2017 Netball World Youth Cup.  Botswana is a member of the Southern African Customs Union

column23: the Commonwealth of Nations
column24: and the United Nations. The country has been adversely affected by the HIV/AIDS epidemic. In 2002

column26: the number of people with AIDS rose from 290
column29: Botswana had the third-highest prevalence rate for HIV/AIDS
column30: with roughly 20% of the population infected. However
column31: in recent years the country has made strides in combatting HIV/AIDS
column32: with efforts being made to provide proper treatment and lower the rate of mother-to-child transmission.  "

column9: 000 square kilometres (240

column1: Canada;"Canada is a country in North America. Its ten provinces and three territories extend from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific Ocean and northward into the Arctic Ocean
column2: making it the world's second-largest country by total area
column3: with the world's longest coastline. Its border with the United States is the world's longest international land border. The country is characterized by a wide range of both meteorologic and geological regions. It is a sparsely inhabited country of 40 million people
column4: the vast majority residing south of the 55th parallel in urban areas. Canada's capital is Ottawa and its three largest metropolitan areas are Toronto
column5: Montreal
column6: and Vancouver.  Indigenous peoples have continuously inhabited what is now Canada for thousands of years. Beginning in the 16th century
column7: British and French expeditions explored and later settled along the Atlantic coast. As a consequence of various armed conflicts
column8: France ceded nearly all of its colonies in North America in 1763. In 1867
column9: with the union of three British North American colonies through Confederation

column13: and culminating in the _Canada Act 1982_
column14: which severed the vestiges of legal dependence on the Parliament of the United Kingdom.  Canada is a parliamentary democracy and a constitutional monarchy in the Westminster tradition. The country's head of government is the prime minister
column15: who holds office by virtue of their ability to command the confidence of the elected House of Commons and is ""called upon"" by the governor general
column16: representing the monarch of Canada
column17: the head of state. The country is a Commonwealth realm and is officially bilingual (English and French) in the federal jurisdiction. It is very highly ranked in international measurements of government transparency
column18: quality of life
column19: economic competitiveness
column20: innovation
column21: education and gender equality. It is one of the world's most ethnically diverse and multicultural nations
column22: the product of large-scale immigration. Canada's long and complex relationship with the United States has had a significant impact on its history
column23: economy
column24: and culture.  A developed country
column25: Canada has a high nominal per capita income globally and its advanced economy ranks among the largest in the world
column26: relying chiefly upon its abundant natural resources and well-developed international trade networks. Canada is recognized as a middle power for its role in international affairs
column27: with a tendency to pursue multilateral solutions. Canada's peacekeeping role during the 20th century has had a significant influence on its global image. Canada is part of multiple major international and intergovernmental institutions.  "

column1: Cocos (Keeling) Islands;"The Cocos (Keeling) Islands (Cocos Islands Malay: _Pulu Kokos [Keeling]_ )
column2: officially the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands (; Cocos Islands Malay: _Pulu Kokos [Keeling]_ )
column3: are an Australian external territory in the Indian Ocean
column4: comprising a small archipelago approximately midway between Australia and Sri Lanka and relatively close to the Indonesian island of Sumatra. The territory's dual name (official since the islands' incorporation into Australia in 1955) reflects that the islands have historically been known as either the Cocos Islands or the Keeling Islands.  The territory consists of two atolls made up of 27 coral islands
column5: of which only two – West Island and Home Island – are inhabited. The population of around 600 people consists mainly of Cocos Malays
column6: who mostly practice Sunni Islam and speak a dialect of Malay as their first language. The territory is administered by the Australian federal government's Department of Infrastructure
column7: Transport
column8: Regional Development
column9: Communications and the Arts as an Australian external territory and together with Christmas Island (which is about 960 kilometres (600 mi) to the east) forms the Australian Indian Ocean Territories administrative grouping. However
column10: the islanders do have a degree of self-government through the local shire council. Many public services – including health
column11: education
column12: and policing – are provided by the state of Western Australia
column13: and Western Australian law applies except where the federal government has determined otherwise. The territory also uses Western Australian postcodes.  The islands were discovered in 1609 by the British sea captain William Keeling
column14: but no settlement occurred until the early 19th century. One of the first settlers was John Clunies-Ross
column15: a Scottish merchant; much of the island's current population is descended from the Malay workers he brought in to work his copra plantation. The Clunies-Ross family ruled the islands as a private fiefdom for almost 150 years
column16: with the head of the family usually recognised as resident magistrate. The British annexed the islands in 1857
column17: and for the next century they were administered from either Ceylon or Singapore. The territory was transferred to Australia in 1955
column18: although until 1979 virtually all of the territory's real estate still belonged to the Clunies-Ross family.  "

column3: is a landlocked country located at the confluence of Western

It joined the United Nations only in 2002 but pursues an active foreign policy that includes frequent involvement in peace building.  Switzerland is the birthplace of the Red Cross and hosts the headquarters or offices of most major international institutions

column27: French

column3: is a country located in western South America. It is the southernmost country in the world and the closest to Antarctica

column5: 949 square kilometers (292
column6: 260 sq mi) and a population of 17.5 million as of 2017

column14: and Easter Island
column15: and claims about 1
column17: 000 square kilometers (480
column18: 000 sq mi) of Antarctica as the Chilean Antarctic Territory. The capital and largest city of Chile is Santiago

column20: replacing Inca rule
column21: but failed to conquer the independent Mapuche people who inhabited what is now south-central Chile. Chile emerged as a relatively stable authoritarian republic in the 1830s after their 1818 declaration of independence from Spain. During the 19th century
column22: Chile experienced significant economic and territorial growth
column23: putting an end to Mapuche resistance in the 1880s and gaining its current northern territory in the War of the Pacific (1879–83) by defeating Peru and Bolivia. In the 20th century

column27: the country was marked by severe left-right political polarization and turmoil

column29: which resulted in more than 3
column30: 000 deaths or disappearances. The regime ended in 1990

column35: per capita income
column36: globalization
column37: peace
column38: and economic freedom. Chile also performs well in the region in terms of sustainability of the state and democratic development

column41: the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC)

column2: officially the People's Republic of China ( PRC )
column3: is a country in East Asia. It is the world's second-most-populous country

column6: 000 sq mi)

column9: four municipalities

column17: including the Han
column18: Tang
column19: Ming
column20: and Qing. Some of China's most notable achievements—such as the invention of gunpowder and paper

column23: traditions
column24: architecture

column26: the monarchy was overthrown and the Republic of China was established. The Republic saw consistent conflict for most of the mid-20th century
column27: including a civil war between the Kuomintang government and the Chinese Communist Party (CCP)

column34: a movement to purge all non-communist elements of Chinese society that led to mass violence and persecution. Beginning in 1978
column35: the Chinese government launched economic reforms that moved the country away from planned economics

Economic reform continued to strengthen the nation's economy in the following decades while raising China's standard of living significantly.  China is a unitary one-party socialist republic led by the CCP. It is one of the five permanent members of the UN Security Council and a founding member of several multilateral and regional organizations such as the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank
column37: the Silk Road Fund
column38: the New Development Bank
column39: and the RCEP. It is a member of the BRICS

column41: APEC
column42: the SCO

column44: transparency
column45: and human rights

column48: and ethnic equality. Making up around one-fifth of the world economy

column2: officially the Republic of Cameroon (French: _République du Cameroun_ )

The country was renamed the United Republic of Cameroon in 1972 and back to the Republic of Cameroon in 1984 by a presidential decree by president Paul Biya. Biya
column19: the incumbent president

column14: where there is an international airport. The census of 2021 put the total population at 14

column1: Christmas Island;The Territory of Christmas Island is an Australian external territory in Southeast Asia comprising the island of the same name. It is located in the Indian Ocean around 350 kilometres (190 nautical miles) south of Java and Sumatra and about 1

column1: Cayman Islands;The Cayman () Islands is a self-governing British Overseas Territory

column3: is an island country situated in the Mediterranean Sea. It lies between the continental mainlands of Europe and Asia

column26: Egyptians
column27: and Persians

column2: officially the Federal Republic of Germany

Formal unification of Germany into the modern nation-state was commenced on 18 August 1866 with the North German Confederation Treaty establishing the Prussia-led North German Confederation later transformed in 1871 into the German Empire. After World War I and the German Revolution of 1918–1919

column15: World War II

column1: Dominica;"Dominica (locally  _dom-in- EE-kə_; UK: US:  or  ;) officially the Commonwealth of Dominica

column10: 747 ft) in elevation. Its population was 71

The unified Kingdom of Denmark emerged in the 8th century AD as a proficient maritime power amid the struggle for control of the Baltic Sea. In 1397

The adoption of the Constitution of Denmark on 5 June 1849 ended the absolute monarchy and introduced the current parliamentary system. An industrialised exporter of agricultural produce in the second half of the 19th century
column33: Denmark introduced social and labour- market reforms in the early 20th century
column34: which formed the basis for the present welfare state model and advanced mixed economy. Denmark remained neutral during World War I; Danish neutrality was violated in World War II by a swift German invasion in April 1940. During occupation

column1: Dominican Republic;"The Dominican Republic ( _də- MIN-ik-ən_; Spanish: _República Dominicana_
column2: pronounced [reˈpuβlika ðominiˈkana] ) is a country on the island of Hispaniola in the Greater Antilles archipelago of the Caribbean Sea
column3: bordered by the Atlantic Ocean to the north. It occupies the eastern five-eighths of the island
column4: which it shares with Haiti
column5: making Hispaniola one of only two Caribbean islands
column6: along with Saint Martin
column7: that is shared by two sovereign states. It is the second-largest nation in the Antilles by area (after Cuba) at 48
column8: 671 square kilometers (18
column9: 792 sq mi)
column10: and third-largest by population
column11: with approximately 10.7 million people in 2022
column12: of whom approximately 3.3 million live in the metropolitan area of Santo Domingo
column13: the capital city.  The native Taíno people had inhabited Hispaniola before the arrival of Europeans
column14: dividing it into five chiefdoms. Christopher Columbus explored and claimed the island for Castile
column15: landing there on his first voyage in 1492. The colony of Santo Domingo became the site of the first permanent European settlement in the Americas and the first seat of Spanish colonial rule in the New World. In 1697
column16: Spain recognized French dominion over the western third of the island
column17: which became the independent state of Haiti in 1804.  The Dominican people declared independence from Spain in November 1821
column18: but were forcefully annexed by Haiti in February 1822. Independence came 22 years later in 1844
column19: after victory in the Dominican War of Independence. Over the next 72 years
column20: the Dominican Republic experienced several civil wars
column21: failed invasions by Haiti
column22: and a brief return to Spanish colonial status
column23: before permanently ousting the Spanish during the Dominican War of Restoration of 1863–1865. The U.S. occupied the Dominican Republic (1916–1924) due to threats of defaulting on foreign debts; a subsequent calm and prosperous six-year period under Horacio Vásquez followed.  From 1930 the dictatorship of Rafael Leónidas Trujillo ruled until his assassination in 1961. Juan Bosch was elected president in 1962 but was deposed in a military coup in 1963. A civil war in 1965
column24: the country's last
column25: was ended by U.S. military intervention and was followed by the authoritarian rule of Joaquín Balaguer (1966–1978 and 1986–1996). Since 1978
column26: the Dominican Republic has moved toward representative democracy.  The Dominican Republic has the largest economy (according to the U.S. State Department and the World Bank) in the Caribbean and Central American region and is the seventh-largest economy in Latin America. Over the last 25 years
column27: the Dominican Republic has had the fastest-growing economy in the Western Hemisphere – with an average real GDP growth rate of 5.3% between 1992 and 2018. GDP growth in 2014 and 2015 reached 7.3 and 7.0%
column28: respectively
column29: the highest in the Western Hemisphere. Recent growth has been driven by construction
column30: manufacturing
column31: tourism
column32: and mining. The country is the site of the third largest gold mine in the world
column33: the Pueblo Viejo mine.  The Dominican Republic is the most visited destination in the Caribbean. The year-round golf courses and resorts are major attractions. A geographically diverse nation

column35: Pico Duarte
column36: and the Caribbean's largest lake and lowest point
column37: Lake Enriquillo. The island has an average temperature of 26 °C (78.8 °F) and great climatic and biological diversity.  The country is also the site of the first cathedral

column42: a World Heritage Site. The Dominican Republic is highly vulnerable to natural disasters.  "

column15: and the 32nd-most populous country in the world. The capital and largest city is Algiers

The Sétif and Guelma massacre in 1945 marked a turning point in Franco-Algerian relations and sparked the Algerian War which concluded with Algeria gaining its independence on 5 July 1962 and the proclamation of the People's Democratic Republic on 25 September of that year.  The official languages of Algeria are Arabic and Berber. The majority of Algeria's population is Arab

column1: Ecuador;"Ecuador ( _EK -wə-dor_; Spanish pronunciation: [ekwaˈðoɾ] ; Quechua: _Ikwayur_ ; Shuar: _Ecuador_ or _Ekuatur_ )

The short-lived republic that followed was beset by the ramifications of civil strife and the challenge of resettling refugees from Turkey. In 1936 a royalist dictatorship inaugurated a long period of authoritarian rule
column38: marked by military occupation during World War II
column39: civil war

column52: and prominent shipping sector. The country's rich historical legacy is reflected in part by its 19 UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

column1: Grenada;"Grenada ( _grə- NAY-də_; Grenadian Creole French: _Gwenad_ ) is an island country in the West Indies in the Caribbean Sea at the southern end of the Grenadines island chain. Grenada consists of the island of Grenada itself

column6: and it had an estimated population of 124
column7: 523 in July 2021. Its capital is St. George's. Grenada is also known as the ""Island of Spice"" due to its production of nutmeg and mace crops.  Before the arrival of Europeans in the Americas
column8: Grenada was inhabited by the indigenous peoples from South America. Christopher Columbus sighted Grenada in 1498 during his third voyage to the Americas. Following several unsuccessful attempts by Europeans to colonise the island due to resistance from resident Island Caribs

column10: Grenada was ceded to the British under the Treaty of Paris. British rule continued until 1974 (except for a brief French takeover between 1779 and 1783). However
column11: on 3 March 1967
column12: it was granted full autonomy over its internal affairs as an Associated State
column13: and from 1958 to 1962 Grenada was part of the Federation of the West Indies
column14: a short-lived federation of British West Indian colonies.  Independence was granted on 7 February 1974 under the leadership of Eric Gairy
column15: who became the first prime minister of Grenada of the sovereign state. The new country became a member of the Commonwealth of Nations
column16: with Queen Elizabeth II as head of state. In March 1979
column17: the Marxist–Leninist New Jewel Movement overthrew Gairy's government in a bloodless _coup d'état_ and established the People's Revolutionary Government (PRG)
column18: headed by Maurice Bishop as prime minister. Bishop was later arrested and executed by members of the People's Revolutionary Army (PRA)
column19: which was used to justify a U.S.-led invasion in October 1983. Since then
column20: the island has returned to a parliamentary representative democracy and has remained politically stable. The country is currently headed by King Charles III
column21: King of Grenada.  "

column3: pronounced [ˈkʁɶnˌlænˀ]) is a North American autonomous territory of the Kingdom of Denmark. It is the largest country within the Kingdom and one of three countries which form the Kingdom
column4: the others being Denmark proper and the Faroe Islands; the citizens of all three countries are citizens of Denmark. As Greenland is one of the Overseas Countries and Territories of the European Union
column5: citizens of Greenland are also granted European Union citizenship. The capital and largest city of Greenland is Nuuk. Greenland lies between the Arctic and Atlantic oceans

column10: the colonial powers) for more than a millennium
column11: beginning in 986. Greenland has been inhabited at intervals over at least the last 4
column12: 500 years by Arctic peoples whose forebears migrated there from what is now Canada. Norsemen settled the uninhabited southern part of Greenland beginning in the 10th century
column13: having previously settled Iceland. Inuit arrived in the 13th century. Though under continuous influence of Norway and Norwegians

column15: after Norway was hit by the Black Death and entered a severe decline.  In the early 17th century
column16: Dano-Norwegian explorers reached Greenland again. When Denmark and Norway separated in 1814
column17: Greenland became Danish
column18: and was fully integrated in the Danish state in 1953 under the Constitution of Denmark
column19: which made the people in Greenland citizens of Denmark. In 1979
column20: Denmark granted home rule to Greenland; in 2008
column21: Greenlanders voted for the Self-Government Act
column22: which transferred more power from the Danish government to the local Greenlandic government. Under the new structure
column23: Greenland has gradually assumed responsibility for a number of governmental services and areas of competence. The Danish government retains control of citizenship
column24: monetary policy
column25: and foreign affairs
column26: including defence. Most residents of Greenland are Inuit. The population is concentrated mainly on the southwest coast
column27: and the rest of the island is sparsely populated. Three-quarters of Greenland is covered by the only permanent ice sheet outside Antarctica. With a population of 56
column29: Greenland is the least densely populated region in the world. 67% of its electricity production comes from renewable energy
column30: mostly from hydropower.  "

column2: officially the Republic of Guatemala (Spanish: _República de Guatemala_ )

column10: the most populous city in Central America.  The territory of modern Guatemala hosted the core of the Maya civilization

column16: it was ruled by a series of dictators backed by the United Fruit Company and the United States government. In 1944
column17: authoritarian leader Jorge Ubico was overthrown by a pro-democratic military coup
column18: initiating a decade-long revolution that led to sweeping social and economic reforms. A U.S.-backed military coup in 1954 ended the revolution and installed a dictatorship.  From 1960 to 1996
column19: Guatemala endured a bloody civil war fought between the U.S.-backed government and leftist rebels
column20: including genocidal massacres of the Maya population perpetrated by the military. A peace accord negotiated by the United Nations has resulted in continued economic growth and successful democratic elections
column21: although poverty
column22: crime
column23: drug trafficking
column24: and civil instability remain major issues.  Although rich in export goods
column25: around a quarter of the population (4.6 million) face food insecurity
column26: which has been worsened by the ongoing food crisis resulting from the Russian invasion of Ukraine.  Guatemala's abundance of biologically significant and unique ecosystems includes many endemic species and contributes to Mesoamerica's designation as a biodiversity hotspot.  "

column1: French Guiana;"French Guiana ( or ; French: _Guyane_ [ɡɥijan] ; French Guianese Creole: _Lagwiyann_ or _Gwiyann_

column3: French Guiana covers a land area of 83
column5: 253 sq mi)
column6: and is inhabited by 301
column7: 099 people.  French Guiana is the second-largest region of France (more than one-seventh the size of Metropolitan France) and the largest outermost region within the European Union. It has a very low population density
column8: with only 3.6 inhabitants per square kilometre (9.3/sq mi). Half of its 301
column9: 099 inhabitants in 2023 lived in the metropolitan area of Cayenne

column12: which is the largest national park in the European Union

column16: the French Guiana Assembly (French: _assemblée de Guyane_ )
column17: replaced the former regional council and departmental council

The border between French Guiana and Brazil is the longest land border that France shares with another country

column3: officially the Co-operative Republic of Guyana

column24: Chinese
column25: Portuguese
column26: other European

column1: Hong Kong;"Hong Kong (US:  or UK: ; Chinese: 香港; Cantonese Yale: _Hēunggóng_
column3: officially the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China (abbr. Hong Kong SAR or HKSAR )

Hong Kong was established as a colony of the British Empire after the Qing dynasty ceded Hong Kong Island in 1841–1842 as a consequence of losing the First Opium War. The colony expanded to the Kowloon Peninsula in 1860 and was further extended when the United Kingdom obtained a 99-year lease of the New Territories in 1898. Hong Kong was occupied by Japan from 1941 to 1945 during World War II. The whole territory was transferred from the United Kingdom to China in 1997. Hong Kong maintains separate governing and economic systems from that of mainland China under the principle of ""one country
column7: two systems"".  Originally a sparsely populated area of farming and fishing villages

column11: the Hong Kong dollar

column15: housing in Hong Kong has been well-documented to experience a chronic persistent shortage.  Hong Kong is a highly developed territory and has a Human Development Index (HDI) of 0.952
column16: ranking fourth in the world. The city has the highest life expectancy in the world
column17: and a public transport rate exceeding 90%.  "

column1: Heard Island and McDonald Islands;The Territory of Heard Island and McDonald Islands ( HIMI ) is an Australian external territory comprising a volcanic group of mostly barren Antarctic islands

column23: which are uninhabited

column17: its Inequality-adjusted Human Development Index is 0.443.  Honduran society is predominantly Mestizo; however

column1: Hungary;"Hungary (Hungarian: _Magyarország_ [ˈmɒɟɒrorsaːɡ] ) is a landlocked country in Central Europe. Spanning 93

column1: Isle of Man;The Isle of Man (Manx: _Mannin_ [ˈmanɪnʲ]

column2: officially the Republic of India (ISO: _Bhārat Gaṇarājya_ )

column11: Myanmar

column17: 000 years ago

column29: Christianity
column30: Islam
column31: Judaism

column34: and drawing northern India into the cosmopolitan networks of medieval Islam. In the 15th century

column54: with an expanding middle class. India has a space programme with several planned or completed extraterrestrial missions. It is the fourth country to land a craft on the moon and the first to do so within 600 kilometres (370 mi) of the Lunar south pole. Indian movies

column64: which has traditionally been viewed with tolerance in India's culture

column1: British Indian Ocean Territory;The British Indian Ocean Territory ( BIOT ) is an Overseas Territory of the United Kingdom situated in the Indian Ocean

column1: Ireland;"Ireland ( _YRE -lənd_; Irish: _Éire_ [ˈeːɾʲə] ; Ulster-Scots: _Airlann_ [ˈɑːrlən]) is an island in the North Atlantic Ocean

column8: an independent state covering five-sixths of the island
column9: and Northern Ireland

column15: woodland makes up about 10% of the island

column17: with most of it being non-native conifer plantations. The Irish climate is influenced by the Atlantic Ocean and thus very moderate

column21: English rule did not extend over the whole island until the 16th–17th century Tudor conquest

column23: a system of Protestant English rule was designed to materially disadvantage the Catholic majority and Protestant dissenters

column30: both the Republic of Ireland and the United Kingdom
column31: with Northern Ireland as part of it
column32: joined the European Economic Community. Following a referendum vote in 2016
column33: the United Kingdom
column34: Northern Ireland included

Northern Ireland was granted a limited special status and allowed to operate within the EU single market for goods without being in the European Union; the economy has subsequently grown faster than the rest of the UK.  Irish culture has had a significant influence on other cultures

column3: is a country in West Asia and in the geopolitical region known as the Middle East. With a population of over 45 million

column37: led by Ahmad Hassan al-Bakr and then by Saddam Hussein

A 2003 invasion launched by another US-led coalition as part of its ""Global War on Terror"" resulted in the defeat of Ba'athist Iraq and the execution of Saddam Hussein. Discontent with the de-Ba'athification policies of the Provisional Authority stirred up an anti-American insurgency
column43: which escalated into a sectarian civil war. In 2005

column46: after which a coalition of Ba'athist and Sunni militias took up arms during the 2013 Anbar campaign. The climax of the campaign was the Northern Iraq offensive by the Islamic State group that marked its rapid territorial expansion

column2: pronounced [ˈistlant] ) is a Nordic island country between the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans

column6: 000 residents. The official language of the country is Icelandic.  Located on a rift between tectonic plates

column23: and Sweden. Iceland thus followed Norway's integration into that union

column31: Iceland relied largely on subsistence fishing and agriculture. Industrialization of the fisheries and Marshall Plan aid following World War II brought prosperity
column32: and Iceland became one of the wealthiest and most developed nations in the world. It became a part of the European Economic Area in 1994; this further diversified the economy into sectors such as finance
column33: biotechnology
column34: and manufacturing.  Iceland has a market economy with relatively low taxes
column35: compared to other OECD countries
column36: as well as the highest trade union membership in the world. It maintains a Nordic social welfare system that provides universal health care and tertiary education for its citizens. Iceland ranks highly in international comparisons of national performance
column37: such as quality of life
column38: education
column39: protection of civil liberties
column40: government transparency
column41: and economic freedom.  Icelandic culture is founded upon the nation's Scandinavian heritage. Most Icelanders are descendants of Norse and Gaelic settlers. Icelandic
column42: a North Germanic language

column44: Icelandic literature
column45: and medieval sagas. Iceland has the smallest population of any NATO member and is the only one with no standing army
column46: possessing only a lightly armed coast guard.  "

column26: and British. While Christianity has been present since the time of the early Christians

column28: serving as the headquarters for the British Mediterranean Fleet. It was besieged by the Axis powers during World War II and was an important Allied base for operations in North Africa and the Mediterranean. The British parliament passed the Malta Independence Act in 1964
column29: giving Malta independence
column30: with Elizabeth II as its queen. The country became a republic in 1974. It has been a member state of the Commonwealth of Nations and the United Nations since independence
column31: and joined the European Union in 2004; it became part of the eurozone monetary union in 2008. Malta is also closely tied historically and culturally to Italy and specifically Sicily
column32: with between 62 to 66 percent of Maltese people speaking or having significant knowledge of the Italian language
column33: which was one of the official languages of Malta until 1934.  Catholicism is the state religion
column34: but the Constitution of Malta guarantees freedom of conscience and religious worship. The economy of Malta is heavily reliant on tourism
column35: and the country promotes itself as a Mediterranean tourist destination with its warmer climate compared to the rest of Europe
column36: numerous recreational areas
column37: and architectural and historical monuments
column38: including three UNESCO World Heritage Sites: Ħal Saflieni Hypogeum
column39: Valletta
column40: and seven megalithic temples which are some of the oldest free-standing structures in the world.  "

column1: Myanmar;"Myanmar (Burmese: မြန်မာ; MLCTS: _Mranma_
column3: officially the Republic of the Union of Myanmar (Burmese: ပြည်ထောင်စု သမ္မတ မြန်မာနိုင်ငံတော်; MLCTS: _Pranyhtaungcu. Sa.ma.ta. Mranma Nuingngamtau_ ; pronounced [pjìdàʊɴzṵ θàɴməda̰ mjəmà nàɪɴŋàɴdɔ̀])
column4: also known as Burma (the official name until 1989)
column5: is a country in Southeast Asia. It is the largest country by area in Mainland Southeast Asia and has a population of about 55 million. It is bordered by Bangladesh and India to its northwest
column6: China to its northeast
column7: Laos and Thailand to its east and southeast
column8: and the Andaman Sea and the Bay of Bengal to its south and southwest. The country's capital city is Naypyidaw
column9: and its largest city is Yangon (formerly Rangoon).  Early civilisations in the area included the Tibeto-Burman-speaking Pyu city- states in Upper Myanmar and the Mon kingdoms in Lower Myanmar. In the 9th century
column10: the Bamar people entered the upper Irrawaddy valley
column11: and following the establishment of the Pagan Kingdom in the 1050s
column12: the Burmese language
column13: culture
column14: and Theravada Buddhism slowly became dominant in the country. The Pagan Kingdom fell to Mongol invasions
column15: and several warring states emerged. In the 16th century
column16: reunified by the Taungoo dynasty
column17: the country became the largest empire in the history of Southeast Asia for a short period. The early 19th-century Konbaung dynasty ruled over an area that included modern Myanmar and briefly controlled Manipur and Assam as well. The British East India Company seized control of the administration of Myanmar after three Anglo- Burmese Wars in the 19th century
column18: and the country became a British colony. After a brief Japanese occupation
column19: Myanmar was reconquered by the Allies. On 4 January 1948
column20: Myanmar declared independence under the terms of the Burma Independence Act 1947.  Myanmar's post-independence history has continued to be checkered by unrest and conflict. The coup d'état in 1962 resulted in a military dictatorship under the Burma Socialist Programme Party. On 8 August 1988
column21: the 8888 Uprising then resulted in a nominal transition to a multi-party system two years later
column22: but the country's post-uprising military council refused to cede power
column23: and has continued to rule the country through to the present. The country remains riven by ethnic strife among its myriad ethnic groups and has one of the world's longest-running ongoing civil wars. The United Nations and several other organisations have reported consistent and systemic human rights violations in the country. In 2011
column24: the military junta was officially dissolved following a 2010 general election
column25: and a nominally civilian government was installed. Aung San Suu Kyi and political prisoners were released and the 2015 Myanmar general election was held
column26: leading to improved foreign relations and eased economic sanctions
column27: although the country's treatment of its ethnic minorities
column28: particularly in connection with the Rohingya conflict
column29: continued to be a source of international tension and consternation. Following the 2020 Myanmar general election
column30: in which Aung San Suu Kyi's party won a clear majority in both houses
column31: the Burmese military (Tatmadaw) again seized power in a coup d'état. The coup
column32: which was widely condemned by the international community
column33: led to continuous ongoing widespread protests in Myanmar and has been marked by violent political repression by the military
column34: as well as a larger outbreak of the civil war. The military also arrested Aung San Suu Kyi in order to remove her from public life
column35: and charged her with crimes ranging from corruption to the violation of COVID-19 protocols; all of the charges against her are ""politically motivated"" according to independent observers.  Myanmar is a member of the East Asia Summit
column36: Non-Aligned Movement
column37: ASEAN
column38: and BIMSTEC
column39: but it is not a member of the Commonwealth of Nations despite once being part of the British Empire. Myanmar is a Dialogue Partner of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization. The country is very rich in natural resources
column40: such as jade
column41: gems
column42: oil
column43: natural gas
column44: teak and other minerals
column45: as well as also endowed with renewable energy
column46: having the highest solar power potential compared to other countries of the Great Mekong Subregion. However
column47: Myanmar has long suffered from instability
column48: factional violence
column49: corruption
column51: as well as a long history of colonial exploitation with little regard to human development. In 2013
column52: its GDP (nominal) stood at US$56.7 billion and its GDP (PPP) at US$221.5 billion. The income gap in Myanmar is among the widest in the world
column53: as a large proportion of the economy is controlled by cronies of the military junta. Myanmar is one of the least developed countries; as of 2020
column54: according to the Human Development Index
column55: it ranks 147 out of 189 countries in terms of human development
column56: the lowest in Southeast Asia. Since 2021
column58: 000 people were displaced across Myanmar due to the surge in violence post-coup
column59: with more than 3 million people in dire need of humanitarian assistance.  "

column2: -⁠AY-groh_; Montenegrin: _Crna Gora_ / Црна Гора; Albanian: _Mali i Zi_ ; lit. 'Black Mountain') is a country in Southeast Europe. It is bordered by Bosnia and Herzegovina to the north
column3: Serbia to the northeast
column4: Kosovo to the east
column5: Albania to the southeast
column6: and Croatia and the Adriatic Sea to the northwest with a coastline of 293.5 km. Podgorica (Cyrillic: Подгорица) is the country's capital and its largest city. It covers 10.4% of Montenegro's territory of 13
column7: 812 square kilometres (5
column8: 333 sq mi)
column9: and is home to roughly 31% of its total population of 621
column10: 000. Cetinje (Cyrillic: Цетиње) is the former royal capital and cultural centre of Montenegro and is the location of several national institutions
column11: including the official residence of the President of Montenegro.  During the Early Medieval period
column12: three principalities were located on the territory of modern-day Montenegro: Duklja
column13: roughly corresponding to the southern half; Travunia
column14: the west; and Rascia proper
column15: the north. The Principality of Zeta emerged in the 14th and 15th centuries. From the late 14th century to the late 18th century
column16: large parts of southern Montenegro were ruled by the Venetian Republic and incorporated into Venetian Albania. The name _Montenegro_ was first used to refer to the country in the late 15th century. After falling under Ottoman Empire rule
column17: Montenegro gained semi- autonomy in 1696 under the rule of the House of Petrović-Njegoš
column18: first as a theocracy and later as a secular principality. Montenegro's independence was recognised by the Great Powers at the Congress of Berlin in 1878. In 1910
column19: the country became a kingdom. After World War I
column20: the kingdom became part of Yugoslavia. Following the breakup of Yugoslavia
column21: the republics of Serbia and Montenegro together proclaimed a federation. In June 2006 Montenegro declared its independence from Serbia and Montenegro following an independence referendum
column22: creating Montenegro and Serbia as they exist today. Montenegro is therefore one of the newest internationally-recognised countries in the world.  Montenegro has an upper-middle-income economy
column23: and ranks 49th in the Human Development Index. It is a member of the United Nations
column24: NATO
column25: the World Trade Organization
column26: the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe
column27: the Council of Europe
column28: and the Central European Free Trade Agreement. Montenegro is also a founding member of the Union for the Mediterranean
column29: and has been in the process of joining the European Union since 2012.    *[lit.]: literal translation  "

column1: Mongolia;"Mongolia ( _mong- GOH-lee-ə_) is a landlocked country in East Asia
column2: bordered by Russia to the north and China to the south. The western extremity of Mongolia is only 23 km (14 mi) from Kazakhstan
column3: and this area can resemble a quadripoint when viewed on a map. It covers an area of 1
column5: 116 square kilometres (603
column6: 909 square miles)
column7: with a population of just 3.3 million
column8: making it the world's most sparsely populated sovereign state. Mongolia is the world's largest landlocked country that does not border a closed sea
column9: and much of its area is covered by grassy steppe
column10: with mountains to the north and west and the Gobi Desert to the south. Ulaanbaatar
column11: the capital and largest city
column12: is home to roughly half of the country's population.  The territory of modern-day Mongolia has been ruled by various nomadic empires
column13: including the Xiongnu
column14: the Xianbei
column15: the Rouran
column16: the First Turkic Khaganate
column17: the Second Turkic Khaganate
column18: the Uyghur Khaganate and others. In 1206
column19: Genghis Khan founded the Mongol Empire
column20: which became the largest contiguous land empire in history. His grandson Kublai Khan conquered China proper and established the Yuan dynasty. After the collapse of the Yuan
column21: the Mongols retreated to Mongolia and resumed their earlier pattern of factional conflict
column22: except during the era of Dayan Khan and Tumen Zasagt Khan. In the 16th century
column23: Tibetan Buddhism spread to Mongolia
column24: being further led by the Manchu-founded Qing dynasty
column25: which absorbed the country in the 17th century. By the early 20th century
column26: almost one-third of the adult male population were Buddhist monks. After the collapse of the Qing dynasty in 1911
column27: Mongolia declared independence
column28: and achieved actual independence from the Republic of China in 1921. Shortly thereafter
column29: the country became a satellite state of the Soviet Union. In 1924
column30: the Mongolian People's Republic was founded as a socialist state. After the anti-communist revolutions of 1989
column31: Mongolia conducted its own peaceful democratic revolution in early 1990. This led to a multi-party system
column32: a new constitution of 1992
column33: and transition to a market economy.  Approximately 30% of the population is nomadic or semi-nomadic; horse culture remains integral. Buddhism is the majority religion (51.7%)
column34: with the nonreligious being the second-largest group (40.6%). Islam is the third- largest religious identification (3.2%)
column35: concentrated among ethnic Kazakhs. The vast majority of citizens are ethnic Mongols
column36: with roughly 5% of the population being Kazakhs
column37: Tuvans
column38: and other ethnic minorities
column39: who are especially concentrated in the western regions. Mongolia is a member of the United Nations
column40: Asia Cooperation Dialogue
column42: Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank
column43: Non-Aligned Movement and a NATO global partner. Mongolia joined the World Trade Organization in 1997 and seeks to expand its participation in regional economic and trade groups.  "

column1: Northern Mariana Islands;"The Northern Mariana Islands
column2: officially the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands ( CNMI ; Chamorro: _Sankattan Siha Na Islas Mariånas_ ; Carolinian: _Commonwealth Téél Falúw kka Efáng llól Marianas_ )
column3: is an unincorporated territory and commonwealth of the United States consisting of 14 islands in the northwestern Pacific Ocean. The CNMI includes the 14 northernmost islands in the Mariana Archipelago; the southernmost island
column4: Guam
column5: is a separate U.S. territory. The Northern Mariana Islands were listed by the United Nations as a non-self governing territory until 1990.  The Northern Marianas were part of the United Nations trust territories after World War II under American administration
column6: while previously they had been under the control of the Spanish (1500s–1899)
column7: the Germans (1899–1914)
column8: and the Japanese (1914–1944). In the late 20th century they eventually settled on joining the United States. This process was completed in the late 20th century and recognized internationally
column9: and the people of the Northern Marianas became United States citizens by their choice in 1986. They have one federal representative in Congress. The other U.S. Pacific territories with significant populations are Guam
column10: American Samoa
column11: and Hawaii. The population of the Northern Marianas is several times smaller than the U.S. states
column12: so its representation is handled differently
column13: in that they have more autonomy with a governor and in Congress
column14: but less participation in the federal government. They are U.S. citizens with free movement around the United States and have access to many federal programs
column15: but do not pay federal income tax. The Northern Marianas are near to but separate from Guam which became a part of the USA since 1898. Together Guam
column16: CNMI
column17: American Samoa
column18: and Hawaii represent Pacific peoples of the United States tying together many assets such as marine reserves
column19: atolls
column20: and islands dotting the Pacific.  The United States Department of the Interior cites a landmass of 183.5 square miles (475.26 km2). According to the 2020 United States Census
column22: 329 people were living in the CNMI at that time. The vast majority of the population resides on Saipan
column23: Tinian
column24: and Rota. The other islands of the Northern Marianas are sparsely inhabited; the most notable among these is Pagan
column25: which was left largely uninhabted since a 1981 volanic eruption. The total area of the island chain makes it bigger than American Samoa or U.S. Virgin Islands
column26: but as an island chain the distance between the northernmost island and southernmost
column27: Rota
column28: is roughly over 300 miles (around 500 km) which is nearly 1/3 the length of California
column29: for example (which is over 1000 miles from North to South). The main islands of northern Marianas are
column30: from north to south are: Farallon de Pajaros (or Uracus)
column31: Maug Islands (actually three islands)
column32: Asuncion Island
column33: Agrihan
column34: Pagan
column35: Alamagan
column36: Guguan
column37: Sarigan
column38: Anatahan
column39: Farallon de Medinilla
column40: Saipan
column41: Tinian
column42: Aguijan
column43: and Rota (aka Luta). Of these
column44: most live on Saipan; Tinian and Rota also have populations. The highest point on Saipan is Mount Tapochau on
column46: 555 ft) while the highest point in the Northern Mariana islands is Agrihan at 977 meters
column47: 3204 feet (on Agrihan island). Pagan is home to an active volcano
column48: which had a fairly large eruption in 1981
column49: and had had activity as recently as 2021. The bottom three islands Saipan
column51: and Rota are mostly limestone
column52: but the northern islands are volcanic. To the east of the islands in the Mariana Trench lies some of the deepest ocean on the planet.  The administrative center is Capitol Hill
column53: a village in northwestern Saipan. The current governor of the CNMI is Arnold Palacios
column54: he is the tenth Governor and took office in January 2023. The legislative branch has a 9-member senate
column55: and there is a 14-member House of Representatives. The CNMI joined the United States in the late 20th century
column56: a country with a unique system by which other territories or nations can become states with another country. The U.S. currently has 50 States and 5 territories. Compared to Puerto Rico
column58: which are also U.S. Citizens but do not pay Federal income tax but the CNMI had a much clearer referendum on becoming a part of the U.S. The CNMI's were quite definitive
column59: with over 93 approving the 1977 constitution; by 1986 they were granted U.S. Citizenship and the United Nations acknowledged their choice. In the 21st century
column60: the CNMI maintains their own local government with some variations in local law.  "

column3: officially the Republic of Mozambique ( _República de Moçambique_
column4: pronounced [ʁɛˈpuβlikɐ ðɨ musɐ̃ˈbikɨ])
column5: is a country located in southeastern Africa bordered by the Indian Ocean to the east
column6: Tanzania to the north
column7: Malawi and Zambia to the northwest
column8: Zimbabwe to the west
column9: and Eswatini and South Africa to the southwest. The sovereign state is separated from the Comoros
column10: Mayotte and Madagascar by the Mozambique Channel to the east. The capital and largest city is Maputo.  Between the 7th and 11th centuries
column11: a series of Swahili port towns developed on that area
column12: which contributed to the development of a distinct Swahili culture and dialect. In the late medieval period
column13: these towns were frequented by traders from Somalia
column14: Ethiopia
column15: Egypt
column16: Arabia
column17: Persia
column18: and India. The voyage of Vasco da Gama in 1498 marked the arrival of the Portuguese
column19: who began a gradual process of colonisation and settlement in 1505. After over four centuries of Portuguese rule
column20: Mozambique gained independence in 1975
column21: becoming the People's Republic of Mozambique shortly thereafter. After only two years of independence
column22: the country descended into an intense and protracted civil war lasting from 1977 to 1992. In 1994
column23: Mozambique held its first multiparty elections and has since remained a relatively stable presidential republic
column24: although it still faces a low-intensity insurgency distinctively in the farthermost regions from the southern capital and where Islam is dominant.  Mozambique is endowed with rich and extensive natural resources
column25: notwithstanding the country's economy is based chiefly on fishery—substantially molluscs
column26: crustaceans and echinoderms—and agriculture with a growing industry of food and beverages
column27: chemical manufacturing
column28: aluminium and oil. The tourism sector is expanding. South Africa remains Mozambique's main trading partner
column29: preserving a close relationship with Portugal with a perspective on other European markets. Since 2001
column30: Mozambique's GDP growth has been thriving
column31: but the nation is still one of the poorest and most underdeveloped countries in the world
column32: ranking low in GDP per capita
column33: human development
column34: measures of inequality and average life expectancy.  The country's population of around 30 million
column35: as of 2022 estimates
column36: is composed of overwhelmingly Bantu peoples. However
column37: the only official language in Mozambique is the colonial language of Portuguese
column38: which is spoken in urban areas as a first or second language by most
column39: and generally as a lingua franca between younger Mozambicans with access to formal education. The most important local languages include Tsonga
column40: Makhuwa
column41: Sena
column42: Chichewa
column43: and Swahili. Glottolog lists 46 languages spoken in the country
column44: of which one is a signed language (Mozambican Sign Language/ _Língua de sinais de Moçambique_ ). The largest religion in Mozambique is Christianity
column45: with significant minorities following Islam and African traditional religions. Mozambique is a member of the United Nations
column46: the African Union
column48: the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation
column49: the Community of Portuguese Language Countries
column51: the Southern African Development Community
column52: and is an observer at La Francophonie.  "

column2: officially the Islamic Republic of Mauritania (Arabic: الجمهورية الإسلامية الموريتانية)
column3: is a sovereign country in Northwest Africa. It is bordered by the Atlantic Ocean to the west
column4: Western Sahara to the north and northwest
column5: Algeria to the northeast
column6: Mali to the east and southeast
column7: and Senegal to the southwest. By land area
column8: Mauritania is the 11th-largest country in Africa and the 28th-largest in the world
column9: and 90% of its territory is situated in the Sahara. Most of its population of approximately 4.3 million lives in the temperate south of the country
column10: with roughly one-third concentrated in the capital and largest city
column11: Nouakchott
column12: located on the Atlantic coast.  The country's name derives from the ancient Berber kingdom of Mauretania
column13: located in North Africa within the ancient Maghreb. Berbers occupied what is now Mauritania beginning in the third century AD. Arabs under the Umayyad Caliphate conquered the area in the late seventh century
column14: bringing Islam
column15: Arab culture
column16: and the Arabic language. In the early 20th century
column17: Mauritania was colonized by France as part of French West Africa. It achieved independence in 1960
column18: but has since experienced recurrent coups and periods of military dictatorship. The most recent coup
column20: was led by General Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz
column21: who won subsequent presidential elections in 2009 and 2014. He was succeeded by Mohamed Ould Ghazouani following the 2019 elections
column22: which were considered Mauritania's first peaceful transition of power since independence.  Mauritania is culturally and politically part of the Arab world; it is a member of the Arab League and Arabic is the sole official language. The official religion is Islam
column23: and almost all inhabitants are Sunni Muslims. Despite its prevailing Arab identity
column24: Mauritanian society is multiethnic; the Bidhan
column25: or so-called ""white moors""
column26: make up 30% of the population
column27: while the Haratin
column28: or so-called ""black moors""
column29: comprise 40%. Both groups reflect a fusion of Arab-Berber ethnicity
column30: language
column31: and culture. The remaining 30% of the population comprises various sub-Saharan ethnic groups.  Despite an abundance of natural resources
column32: including iron ore and petroleum
column33: Mauritania remains poor; its economy is based primarily on agriculture
column34: livestock
column35: and fishing. Mauritania is generally seen as having a poor human rights record
column36: and is particularly censured for the perpetuation of slavery as an institution within Mauritanian society. It abolished the practice in 1981
column37: and criminalized the ownership of slaves outright in 2007.  "

column1: Montserrat;"Montserrat ( _MONT -sə-RAT_) is a British Overseas Territory in the Caribbean. It is part of the Leeward Islands
column2: the northern portion of the Lesser Antilles chain of the West Indies. Montserrat is about 16 km (10 mi) long and 11 km (7 mi) wide
column3: with roughly 40 km (25 mi) of coastline. It is nicknamed ""The Emerald Isle of the Caribbean"" both for its resemblance to coastal Ireland and for the Irish ancestry of many of its inhabitants. Montserrat is the only non-fully sovereign full member of the Caribbean Community and the Organisation of Eastern Caribbean States.  On 18 July 1995
column4: the previously dormant Soufrière Hills volcano
column5: in the southern part of the island
column6: became active. Eruptions destroyed Montserrat's Georgian era capital city of Plymouth. Between 1995 and 2000
column7: two-thirds of the island's population was forced to flee
column8: primarily to the United Kingdom
column9: leaving fewer than 1
column10: 200 people on the island in 1997 (rising to nearly 5
column11: 000 by 2016). The volcanic activity continues
column12: mostly affecting the vicinity of Plymouth
column13: including its docking facilities
column14: and the eastern side of the island around the former W. H. Bramble Airport
column15: the remnants of which were buried by flows from volcanic activity on 11 February 2010.  An exclusion zone
column16: encompassing the southern part of the island to as far north as parts of the Belham Valley
column17: was imposed because of the size of the existing volcanic dome and the resulting potential for pyroclastic activity. Visitors are generally not permitted entry into the exclusion zone
column18: but a view of the destruction of Plymouth can be seen from the top of Garibaldi Hill in Isles Bay. Relatively quiet since early 2010
column19: the volcano continues to be closely monitored by the Montserrat Volcano Observatory.  In 2015
column20: it was announced that planning would begin on a new town and port at Little Bay on the northwest coast of the island. While additional plans proceeded
column21: the centre of government and businesses was moved to Brades. After a number of delays
column22: including Hurricanes Irma and Maria in 2017 and the COVID-19 pandemic beginning in early 2020
column23: in June 2022
column24: ground was broken on the Little Bay Port Development Project
column25: a £28 million project funded by the UK and the Caribbean Development Bank.  "

column2: French: [maʁtinik] ; Martinican Creole: _Matinik_ or _Matnik_ ; Kalinago: _Madinina_ or _Madiana_ ) is an island in the Lesser Antilles of the West Indies
column3: in the eastern Caribbean Sea. A part of the French West Indies (Antilles)
column4: Martinique is an overseas department and region and a single territorial collectivity of the French Republic. It is also part of the European Union as an outermost region within the special territories of members of the European Economic Area
column5: but is not part of the Schengen Area or the European Union Customs Union. The currency in use is the euro.  Martinique has a land area of 1
column6: 128 km2 (436 sq mi) and a population of 364
column7: 508 inhabitants as of January 2019. One of the Windward Islands
column8: it lies directly north of Saint Lucia
column9: northwest of Barbados and south of Dominica. Virtually the entire population speaks both French (the sole official language) and Martinican Creole.  "

column3: moʁis] ; Mauritian Creole: _Moris_ [moʁis])
column4: officially the Republic of Mauritius (French: _République de Maurice_ ; Mauritian Creole: _Repiblik Moris_ )
column5: is an island country in the Indian Ocean
column6: about 2
column7: 000 kilometres (1
column8: 100 nautical miles) off the southeastern coast of East Africa
column9: east of Madagascar. It includes the main island (also called Mauritius) and Rodrigues
column10: Agaléga
column11: and St. Brandon. The islands of Mauritius and Rodrigues
column12: along with nearby Réunion (a French overseas department)
column13: are part of the Mascarene Islands. The main island of Mauritius
column14: where most of the people live
column15: has the capital and largest city
column16: Port Louis. The country spans 2
column17: 040 square kilometres (790 sq mi) and has an exclusive economic zone covering 2
column19: 000 square kilometres (670
column20: 000 square nautical miles). Mauritius is one of the most densely populated countries in the world.  It is believed that Arab sailors first discovered the uninhabited island about 975
column21: naming it _Dina Arobi_. Portuguese sailors visited the uninhabited island in 1507; it was given the Portuguese names _Cirne_ and _Do-Cerne_ on early Portuguese maps. A Dutch fleet
column22: under the command of Admiral Van Warwyck
column23: landed at what is now the Grand Port District and took possession of the island in 1598
column24: renaming the uninhabited islands after Maurice
column25: Prince of Orange. The main island was the only known home of the dodo
column26: which became extinct soon after human settlement. A succession of short-lived Dutch attempts at permanent settlement took place over a century with the aim of exploiting the local ebony forests
column27: and of establishing consistent production of sugar and arrack using cane plant cuttings imported from Java along with over three hundred Malagasy slaves; these efforts finally were abandoned. France took control in 1715
column28: renaming the island ""Isle de France"". In 1810
column29: the United Kingdom seized the island; four years later
column30: under the Treaty of Paris
column31: France ceded Mauritius and its dependencies to the United Kingdom. The British colony of Mauritius included Rodrigues
column32: Agaléga
column33: St. Brandon
column34: the Chagos Archipelago
column35: and until 1906 the Seychelles. Mauritius and France dispute sovereignty over the island of Tromelin
column36: because the treaty did not mention it specifically. Mauritius became the British Empire's main sugar- producing colony and remained a primarily sugar-dominated plantation-based colony until independence
column38: the UK split off the Chagos Archipelago from Mauritian territory to create the British Indian Ocean Territory (BIOT). The local population was forcibly expelled and the largest island
column39: Diego Garcia
column40: was leased to the United States. Ruling on the sovereignty dispute between Mauritius and the UK
column41: the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea has ordered the return of the Chagos Islands to Mauritius.  Owing to its geographic location and centuries of colonialism
column42: the people of Mauritius are highly diverse in ethnicity
column43: culture
column44: language and faith. It is the only country in Africa where Hinduism is the most practiced religion. Indo-Mauritians make up the bulk of the population with significant Creole
column45: Sino-Mauritian and Franco-Mauritian minorities. The island's government is closely modelled on the Westminster system and Mauritius is highly ranked for economic and political freedom being the only African country ranked as being a _full democracy_ in the _Democracy Index_. Mauritius is also the continent's only country ranking _very high_ in the Human Development Index. The World Bank classifies the country as having a high-income economy. It ranks highly among the most competitive and most developed economies in Africa. The country has a welfare state; the government provides free universal healthcare
column46: free education up through the tertiary level and free public transportation for students
column48: and the disabled. Mauritius is consistently ranked as the most peaceful African country.  "

column2: officially the Republic of Malawi and formerly known as Nyasaland
column3: is a landlocked country in Southeastern Africa. It is bordered by Zambia to the west
column4: Tanzania to the north and northeast
column5: and Mozambique to the east
column6: south and southwest. Malawi spans over 118
column8: 747 sq mi) and has an estimated population of 19
column10: 566 (as of January 2021). Malawi's capital (and largest city) is Lilongwe. Its second-largest is Blantyre
column11: its third-largest is Mzuzu and its fourth-largest is its former capital
column12: Zomba.  The part of Africa now known as Malawi was settled around the 10th century by migrating Bantu groups. Centuries later
column14: the area was colonised by the British as the British Central African Protectorate
column15: renamed Nyasaland in 1907. In 1953
column16: it became a protectorate within the semi-independent Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland. The Federation was dissolved in 1963. In 1964
column17: the protectorate was ended: Nyasaland became an independent country as a Commonwealth realm under Prime Minister Hastings Banda
column18: and was renamed _Malawi_. Two years later
column19: Banda became president by converting the country into a one-party presidential republic. Declared President for life in 1971
column20: Malawi's next few decades of independence were characterized by Banda's highly repressive dictatorship. Following the introduction of a multiparty system in 1993
column21: Banda was defeated in the 1994 general election. Today
column22: Malawi has a democratic
column23: multi-party republic headed by an elected president and has continued to experience peaceful transitions of power. According to 2023 V-Dem Democracy indices Malawi is ranked 63rd electoral democracy worldwide and 6th electoral democracy in Africa. The country's military
column24: the Malawian Defence Force
column25: includes an army
column26: a navy
column27: and an air wing. Malawi's foreign policy is pro-Western. It maintains positive diplomatic relations with most countries
column28: and participates in several international organisations

column30: the Commonwealth of Nations
column31: the Southern African Development Community (SADC)
column32: the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)
column33: and the African Union (AU).  Malawi is one of the world's least-developed countries. The economy is heavily based on agriculture
column34: and it has a largely rural and rapidly growing population. The Malawian government depends heavily on outside aid to meet its development needs
column35: although the amount needed (and the aid offered) has decreased since 2000. The Malawian government faces challenges in its efforts to build and expand the economy
column36: to improve education
column37: healthcare
column38: and environmental protection
column39: and to become financially independent despite widespread unemployment. Since 2005
column40: Malawi has developed several policies that focus on addressing these issues
column41: and the country's outlook appears to be improving: key indicators of progress in the economy
column42: education
column43: and healthcare were seen in 2007 and 2008.  Malawi has a low life expectancy and high infant mortality. HIV/AIDS is highly prevalent
column44: which both reduces the labour force and requires increased government expenditures. The country has a diverse population that includes native peoples

column1: Malaysia;"Malaysia (UK:  _mə- LAY-zee-ə_; US:  _mə-LAY-zhə_ ; Malay: [malɛjsia] ) is a country in Southeast Asia. The federal constitutional monarchy consists of 13 states and three federal territories
column2: separated by the South China Sea into two regions: Peninsular Malaysia and Borneo's East Malaysia. Peninsular Malaysia shares a land and maritime border with Thailand and maritime borders with Singapore
column3: Vietnam
column4: and Indonesia. East Malaysia shares land and maritime borders with Brunei and Indonesia
column5: as well as a maritime border with the Philippines and Vietnam. Kuala Lumpur is the national capital
column6: the country's largest city
column7: and the seat of the legislative branch of the federal government. Putrajaya is the administrative centre
column8: which represents the seat of both the executive branch (the Cabinet
column9: federal ministries
column10: and federal agencies) and the judicial branch of the federal government. With a population of over 33 million
column11: the country is the world's 43rd-most populous country. Malaysia is tropical and is one of 17 megadiverse countries; it is home to numerous endemic species. Tanjung Piai in the Malaysian state of Johor is the southernmost point of continental Eurasia.  The country has its origins in the Malay kingdoms
column12: which
column13: from the 18th century on
column14: became subject to the British Empire
column15: along with the British Straits Settlements protectorate. During World War Two
column16: British Malaya
column17: along with other nearby British and American colonies

column19: Peninsular Malaysia was unified as the Malayan Union in 1946 and then restructured as the Federation of Malaya in 1948. The country achieved independence on 31 August 1957. On 16 September 1963
column20: independent Malaya united with the then British crown colonies of North Borneo
column21: Sarawak
column22: and Singapore to become Malaysia. In August 1965
column23: Singapore was expelled from the federation and became a separate
column24: independent country.  The country is multiethnic and multicultural
column25: which has a significant effect on its politics. About half the population is ethnically Malay
column26: with minorities of Chinese
column27: Indians
column28: and indigenous peoples. The official language is Malaysian Malay
column29: a standard form of the Malay language. English remains an active second language. While recognising Islam as the official religion
column30: the constitution grants freedom of religion to non-Muslims. The government is modelled on the Westminster parliamentary system
column31: and the legal system is based on common law. The head of state is an elected monarch
column32: chosen from among the nine state sultans every five years. The head of government is the prime minister.  After independence
column33: the gross domestic product (GDP) grew at an average rate of 6.5% per year for almost 50 years. The country's economy has traditionally been driven by its natural resources
column34: but it is expanding into commerce
column35: tourism
column36: and medical tourism. The country has a newly industrialised market economy
column37: ranked fifth-largest in Southeast Asia and 36th-largest in the world. The country is a founding member of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC)
column38: the East Asia Summit (EAS)
column39: and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)
column40: and a member of the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM)
column41: the Commonwealth
column42: and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC).  "

column3: IPA: [maˈore]; Kibushi: _Maori_

column9: a smaller island

column13: with its 310
column14: 022 people according to January 2023 official estimates

column16: 073 per sq mi). The biggest city and prefecture is Mamoudzou on Grande-Terre. The Dzaoudzi–Pamandzi International Airport is located on the neighbouring island of Petite-Terre. The territory is also known as Maore
column17: the native name of its main island.  Mayotte is one of the overseas departments of France as well as one of the 18 regions of France
column18: with the same status as the departments of Metropolitan France. It is an outermost region of the European Union and
column19: as an overseas department of France
column20: part of the eurozone.  French is the official language and is spoken as a second language by an increasing part of the population
column21: with 63% of the population 14 years and older reporting in the 2007 census that they could speak it. The native languages of Mayotte are Shimaore

column28: and Kibushi antalaotsi

column41: as a result of immigration from neighboring islands

column3: officially the Republic of Namibia
column4: is a country in Southern Africa. Its western border is the Atlantic Ocean. It shares land borders with Zambia and Angola to the north

column8: Damara and Nama people. Around the 14th century
column9: immigrating Bantu peoples arrived as part of the Bantu expansion. Since then

column11: the largest being the Ovambo
column12: have dominated the population of the country; since the late 19th century
column13: they have constituted a majority. With a population of an estimated 2.77 million people today
column14: Namibia is one of the most sparsely populated countries in the world.  In 1884
column15: the German Empire established rule over most of the territory
column16: forming a colony known as German South West Africa. Between 1904 and 1908
column17: German troops waged a punitive campaign against the Herero and Nama which escalated into the first genocide of the 20th century. German rule ended during the First World War with a 1915 defeat by South African forces. In 1920
column18: after the end of the war
column19: the League of Nations mandated administration of the colony to South Africa. From 1948
column20: with the National Party elected to power
column21: this included South Africa applying apartheid to what was then known as South West Africa. In the later 20th century
column22: uprisings and demands for political representation by native African political activists seeking independence resulted in the United Nations assuming direct responsibility over the territory in 1966
column23: but the country of South Africa maintained _de facto_ rule. In 1973

column25: following the Namibian War of Independence. However
column26: Walvis Bay and the Penguin Islands remained under South African control until 1994.  Namibia is a stable parliamentary democracy. Agriculture
column27: tourism and the mining industry – including mining for gem diamonds
column28: uranium
column29: gold
column30: silver and base metals – form the basis of its economy
column31: while the manufacturing sector is comparatively small. Namibia is a member state of the United Nations
column32: the Southern African Development Community
column33: the African Union and the Commonwealth of Nations.  "

column1: New Caledonia;"New Caledonia ( _KAL -ih-DOH-nee-ə_; French: _Nouvelle-Calédonie_ [nuvɛl kaledɔni] ) is a _sui generis_ collectivity of overseas France in the southwest Pacific Ocean

column3: French: [niʒɛʁ])

Its predominantly Muslim population of about 25 million lives mostly in clusters in the south and west of the country. The capital Niamey is located in Niger's southwest corner.  Following the spread of Islam to the region
column15: Niger was on the fringes of some states
column16: including the Kanem–Bornu Empire and the Mali Empire before more significant parts of its territory became included in states such as the Sultanate of Agadez and the Songhai Empire. It was colonized by France during the Scramble for Africa as part of French West Africa
column17: becoming a distinct colony in 1922. Since obtaining independence in 1960

The island served as a convict penal settlement from 6 March 1788 until 5 May 1855

column2: officially the Federal Republic of Nigeria
column3: is a country in West Africa. It is situated between the Sahel to the north and the Gulf of Guinea to the south in the Atlantic Ocean. It covers an area of 923
column4: 769 square kilometres (356
column5: 669 sq mi)

column14: is located. The largest city in Nigeria is Lagos
