column16: with the Nok civilization in the 15th century BC marking the first internal unification in the country. The modern state originated with British colonialization in the 19th century
column17: taking its present territorial shape with the merging of the Southern Nigeria Protectorate and Northern Nigeria Protectorate in 1914 by Lord Lugard. The British set up administrative and legal structures while practising indirect rule through traditional chiefdoms in the Nigeria region. Nigeria became a formally independent federation on 1 October 1960. It experienced a civil war from 1967 to 1970
column18: followed by a succession of military dictatorships and democratically elected civilian governments until achieving a stable democracy in the 1999 presidential election. The 2015 general election was the first time an incumbent president failed to be re-elected.  Nigeria is a multinational state inhabited by more than 250 ethnic groups speaking 500 distinct languages

column20: Yoruba in the west

column24: who live mostly in the north

column26: who live mostly in the south; indigenous religions
column27: such as those native to the Igbo and Yoruba ethnicities

column29: the 39th-largest in the world by nominal GDP
column30: and 27th-largest by PPP. Nigeria is often referred to as the Giant of Africa owing to its large population and economy and is considered to be an emerging market by the World Bank. Nigeria is a founding member of the African Union and a member of many international organizations

column3: is the largest country in Central America

column14: dictatorship

column2: ; Niuean: _Niuē_ ) is a self-governing island country in free association with New Zealand. It is situated in the South Pacific Ocean and is part of Polynesia
column3: and predominantly inhabited by Polynesians. The island is commonly referred to as ""The Rock""
column4: which comes from the traditional name ""Rock of Polynesia"".  Niue is located in a triangle between Tonga
column5: Samoa
column6: and the Cook Islands. It is 2
column7: 400 kilometres (1
column8: 500 mi) northeast of New Zealand
column9: and 604 kilometres (375 mi) northeast of Tonga. Niue's land area is about 261.46 square kilometres (100.95 sq mi) and its population was 1
column10: 689 at the Census in 2022. Niue is one of the world's largest coral islands. The terrain of the island has two noticeable levels. The higher level is made up of a limestone cliff running along the coast
column11: with a plateau in the centre of the island reaching approximately 60 metres (200 ft) above sea level. The lower level is a coastal terrace approximately 0.5 km (0.3 miles) wide and about 25–27 metres (80–90 feet) high
column12: which slopes down and meets the sea in small cliffs. A coral reef surrounds the island
column13: with the only major break in the reef being in the central western coast

column15: Alofi. Niue is subdivided into 14 _villages_ (municipalities). Each village has a council that elects its chairperson. The villages are at the same time electoral districts; each village sends an assemblyperson to the Niue Assembly (parliament).  As part of the Realm of New Zealand
column16: New Zealand conducts most diplomatic relations on behalf of Niue. Niueans are citizens of New Zealand and Charles III is Niue's head of state in his capacity as King of New Zealand. Between 90% and 95% of Niuean people live in New Zealand
column17: along with about 70% of the speakers of the Niuean language. Niue is a bilingual country
column18: with 30% of the population speaking both Niuean and English. The percentage of monolingual English-speaking people is only 11%

column23: and is invited
column24: alongside the other non-UN member state
column25: the Cook Islands
column26: to attend United Nations conferences open to ""all states"". Niue has been a member of the Pacific Community since 1980.  "

column3: is a country located in northwestern Europe with overseas territories in the Caribbean. It is the largest of the four constituent countries of the Kingdom of the Netherlands. The Netherlands consists of twelve provinces; it borders Germany to the east and Belgium to the south

column8: English
column9: and Papiamento are official in the Caribbean territories.   _Netherlands_ literally means ""lower countries"" in reference to its low elevation and flat topography

column11: known as _polders_

column18: its trading companies

column23: 160 sq mi)—of which the land area is 33

The Netherlands has been a parliamentary constitutional monarchy with a unitary structure since 1848. The country has a tradition of pillarisation (separation of citizens into groups by religion and political beliefs) and a long record of social tolerance

Its mixed-market advanced economy has the eleventh-highest per capita income globally. The Hague holds the seat of the States General

Norway has an extensive coastline facing the North Atlantic Ocean and the Barents Sea. Harald V of the House of Glücksburg is the current King. Jonas Gahr Støre has been Prime Minister since 2021. As a unitary state with a constitutional monarchy

Norway has both administrative and political subdivisions on two levels: counties and municipalities. The Sámi people have a certain amount of self- determination and influence over traditional territories through the Sámi Parliament and the Finnmark Act. Norway maintains close ties with the European Union and the United States. Norway is a founding member of the United Nations

column1: New Zealand;"New Zealand (Māori: _Aotearoa_ [aɔˈtɛaɾɔa]) is an island country in the southwestern Pacific Ocean. column1: Puerto Rico;"Puerto Rico (Spanish for 'rich port'; abbreviated PR ; Taino: _Borikén_

column2: officially the Republic of Paraguay (Spanish: _República del Paraguay_ ; Guarani: _Paraguái Tavakuairetã_ )

column1: French Polynesia;"French Polynesia ( _POL -in-EE-zhə_; French: _Polynésie française_ [pɔlinezi fʁɑ̃sɛːz]; Tahitian: _Pōrīnetia Farāni_ ) is an overseas collectivity of France and its sole overseas country. column3: officially the Republic of Rwanda

column15: it is the fifth most densely populated country in the world. Its capital and largest city is Kigali.  Hunter-gatherers settled the territory in the Stone and Iron Ages

column17: and then
column18: into kingdoms. In the 15th century

column29: who retained the pro-Hutu policy. The Tutsi-led Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) launched a civil war in 1990. Habyarimana was assassinated in April 1994. Social tensions erupted in the Rwandan genocide that spanned one hundred days. The RPF ended the genocide with a military victory in July 1994.  Rwanda has been governed as _de facto_ one-party state by the RPF since 1994 with former commander Paul Kagame as President since 2000. The country has been governed by a series of centralized authoritarian governments since precolonial times. Although Rwanda has low levels of corruption compared with neighbouring countries

column34: Tutsi and Twa. The Twa are a forest-dwelling pygmy people and are often considered descendants of Rwanda's earliest inhabitants. Christianity is the largest religion in the country; the principal and national language is Kinyarwanda

column2: officially the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia ( KSA )

The Gulf of Aqaba in the northwest separates Saudi Arabia from Egypt and Israel. Saudi Arabia is the only country with a coastline along both the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf
column8: and most of its terrain consists of arid desert
column9: lowland
column10: steppe

column12: the territory that constitutes modern-day Saudi Arabia

column33: Saudi Arabia defines itself as a sovereign Arab Islamic state with Islam as its official religion and Arabic as its official language. Petroleum was discovered in 1938 and followed up by several other finds in the Eastern Province. Saudi Arabia has since become the world's third-largest oil producer and largest oil exporter
column34: controlling the world's second-largest oil reserves and the sixth-largest gas reserves. The kingdom is categorized as a World Bank high-income economy and is the only Arab country to be part of the G20 major economies. The Saudi government has attracted criticism for various policies such as its intervention in the Yemeni Civil War
column35: alleged sponsorship of terrorism as well as for its domestic repression.  Saudi Arabia is considered both a regional and middle power. The Saudi economy is the largest in the Middle East; the world's nineteenth-largest economy by nominal GDP and the seventeenth largest by PPP. As a country with a very high Human Development Index
column36: it offers a tuition-free university education

column1: South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands;"South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands ( SGSSI ) is a British Overseas Territory in the southern Atlantic Ocean. It is a remote and inhospitable collection of islands

column9: it had been governed as part of the Falkland Islands Dependencies. Argentina claimed South Georgia in 1927 and claimed the South Sandwich Islands in 1938.  Argentina maintained a naval station
column10: Corbeta Uruguay

column14: Toothfish Day is celebrated on 4 September as a bank holiday in the territory.  "

column2: officially the Federal Republic of Somalia (Somali: _Jamhuuriyadda Federaalka Soomaaliya_ ; Arabic: جمهورية الصومال الفيدرالية)

column1: Tokelau;"Tokelau (; lit. 'north-northeast' or 'north wind'; known previously as the Union Islands

The Romans introduced Christianity and left architectural legacies like the Amphitheatre of El Jem. In the 7th century AD

column2: formerly known as the Ellice Islands

column13: according to well established theories regarding a migration of Polynesians into the Pacific that began about three thousand years ago. Long before European contact with the Pacific islands

column1: United States;"The United States of America ( USA )
column2: commonly known as the United States ( U.S. ) or America

column7: Cuba
column8: Russia

column11: D.C.
column12: and its most populous city and principal financial center is New York City.  The first inhabitants of North America migrated across the Bering land bridge at least 12
column13: 000 years ago. Beginning in 1607

column15: which led to the American Revolution and the ensuing Revolutionary War. The United States declared independence on July 4

column20: spanning the continent by 1848. Sectional division over slavery led to the secession of the Confederate States of America
column21: which fought the remaining states of the Union during the American Civil War (1861–65). With the Union's victory and preservation
column22: slavery was abolished nationally. Reforms

column27: the U.S. entered World War II on the side of the Allies. The aftermath of the war left the U.S. and the Soviet Union as the world's two superpowers and led to the Cold War
column28: during which both countries engaged in a struggle for ideological dominance and international influence

column32: it emerged as the world's sole superpower. The 2020s saw the United States emerge as the leader of the AI spring
column33: which has led to rapid and unprecedented development in artificial intelligence.  The United States government is a federal presidential constitutional republic and liberal democracy with three separate branches of government: legislative
column34: executive

column4: officially the Republic of Uzbekistan ( _Oʻzbekiston Respublikasi_

column6: is a country located in Central Asia. It is surrounded by five countries: Kazakhstan to the north; Kyrgyzstan to the northeast; Tajikistan to the southeast; Afghanistan to the south; and Turkmenistan to the southwest. Uzbekistan is part of the Turkic world

Conquests by Emperor Babur towards the east led to the foundation of the Mughal Empire in India. All of Central Asia was gradually incorporated into the Russian Empire during the 19th century

column1: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines;"Saint Vincent and the Grenadines ( _GREH -nə-DEENZ_) is an island country in the eastern Caribbean. It is located in the southeast Windward Islands of the Lesser Antilles

column1: Vanuatu;"Vanuatu (English:  _VAH -noo-AH-too_ or  _van- WAH-too_; Bislama and French pronunciation [vanuatu])

column8: 090 mi) east of northern Australia

This ongoing conflict has led to a severe humanitarian crisis and received widespread criticism for its devastating impact on Yemen's people.  The ongoing humanitarian crisis and conflict has received widespread criticism for having a dramatic worsening effect on Yemen's humanitarian situation
column32: that some say has reached the level of a ""humanitarian disaster"" and some have even labelled it as a genocide. Yemen is one of the least developed countries in the world

column2: officially the Republic of South Africa

column17: as the seat of Parliament

column20: Asian (Indian South Africans and Chinese South Africans)
column21: and multiracial (Coloured South Africans) ancestry. South Africa is a multiethnic society encompassing a wide variety of cultures

The next two are of European origin: Afrikaans (13.5%) developed from Dutch and serves as the first language of most Coloured and White South Africans; English (9.6%) reflects the legacy of British colonialism and is commonly used in public and commercial life.  Regular elections have been held for almost a century in the country. However
column26: the vast majority of Black South Africans were not enfranchised until 1994. During the 20th century
column27: the black majority sought to claim more rights from the dominant white minority
column28: which played a large role in the country's recent history and politics. The National Party imposed apartheid in 1948

column32: which comprises a parliamentary republic and nine provinces. South Africa is often referred to as the ""rainbow nation"" to describe the country's multicultural diversity
column33: especially in the wake of apartheid. According to 2023 V-Dem Democracy indices South Africa is ranked 51st electoral democracy worldwide and 3rd electoral democracy in Africa.  South Africa is a middle power in international affairs; it maintains significant regional influence and is a member of both the Commonwealth of Nations and the G20. It is a developing country
column34: ranking 109th on the Human Development Index

column2: officially the Republic of Zambia (Bemba: _Icalo ca Zambia_ ; Tonga: _Cisi ca Zambia_ ; Tumbuka: _Chalo cha Zambia_ ; Lozi: _Naha ya Zambia_ ; Chichewa: _Dziko la Zambia_ )
column3: is a landlocked country at the crossroads of Central

column15: Zambia was governed by an administration appointed from London with the advice of the British South Africa Company.  On 24 October 1964
column16: Zambia became independent of the United Kingdom and prime minister Kenneth Kaunda became the inaugural president. Kaunda's socialist United National Independence Party (UNIP) maintained power from 1964 until 1991. Kaunda played a key role in regional diplomacy
column17: cooperating closely with the United States in search of solutions to conflicts in Southern Rhodesia (Zimbabwe)
column18: Angola
column19: and Namibia. From 1972 to 1991 Zambia was a one-party state with UNIP as the sole legal political party under the motto ""One Zambia

column23: wildlife
column24: forestry
column25: freshwater and arable land. In 2010
column26: the World Bank named Zambia one of the world's fastest economically reformed countries. The Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) is headquartered in Lusaka.  "

column3: is a landlocked country in Southern Africa

column13: with English

The British South Africa Company of Cecil Rhodes demarcated the Rhodesia region in 1890 when they conquered Mashonaland and later in 1893 Matabeleland after the First Matabele War. Company rule ended in 1923 with the establishment of Southern Rhodesia as a self-governing British colony. In 1965
column23: the white minority government unilaterally declared independence as Rhodesia. The state endured international isolation and a 15-year guerrilla war with black nationalist forces; this culminated in a peace agreement that established _de jure_ sovereignty as Zimbabwe in April 1980.  Robert Mugabe became Prime Minister of Zimbabwe in 1980
column24: when his ZANU–PF party won the general election following the end of white minority rule and has remained the country's dominant party since. He was the President of Zimbabwe from 1987
column25: after converting the country's initial parliamentary system into a presidential one
column26: until his resignation in 2017. Under Mugabe's authoritarian regime
column27: the state security apparatus dominated the country and was responsible for widespread human rights violations. From 1997 to 2008 the economy experienced consistent decline (and in the latter years
column28: hyperinflation)
column29: though it has since seen rapid growth after the use of currencies other than the Zimbabwean dollar was permitted. In 2017
column30: in the wake of over a year of protests against his government as well as Zimbabwe's rapidly declining economy
column31: a coup d'état resulted in Mugabe's resignation. Emmerson Mnangagwa has since served as Zimbabwe's president.  "
